newsitem.title: USA: Away on Business: Speaking their language.
newsitem.headline: Away on Business: Speaking their language.

text.p: The business traveller faced with a sudden overseas assignment has a growing number of ways to break the language barrier.

One of the most sophisticated comes in a recently introduced product from Learning Co. Inc. which teaches basic language skills with an interactive computer programme allowing the user to talk his or her way through common travel situations.
It is available now in Spanish and French and will soon be marketed as well in German, Italian and Japanese.
The CD-ROM product called "Travel Talk" is designed for use with Windows 95 or Windows 3.1 on systems with voice capabilities and a microphone.
"It simulates complete tasks. You might, for instance, catch a cab, ask to go to a restaurant, order a meal, and the characters on the screen respond," said company spokesman Rob Linder.
If you order coffee the figure on the screen brings you a cup. If you ask the hotel desk clerk to pay your bill with a credit card, the simulated desk clerk on the screen responds accordingly.

The product, which the company said has been selling well, is designed for basic conversational skills -- enough to get a stranger through customs, around a city and in and out of various common situations.

The company also markets a deeper and more detailed language product series called "We Learn to Speak." The Travel Talk product is available at retail stores in North America and internationally, and sells for from $54 to $60.
For the traveller in an even bigger hurry, there is another product that requires no more skill than finger pointing.

Called Kwikpoint, it is a laminated suitcoat pocket-sized accordion fold card with dozens of images in more than 40 categories. At a loss for words but hungry for an ice cream cone? point to the picture of one in the box marked "snacks/sweets."
Camera film, embassies, gambling casinos, tow trucks and copying machines are illustrated along with cigarettes, sun tan lotion, barbers and dentists.
The product sells for under $5 and is available at book and map stores. Its developers say 200,000 of the Kwikpoints have been sold and it is standard issue for the U.S. Marine Corps.
It has been on the market for about five years and is now in its second version, which is larger than the first.
